                                                 Draft version June 30, 2021
                                                 Typeset using LATEX twocolumn style in AASTeX63




                                                           Observation of gravitational waves from two neutron star–black hole coalescences

                                                       The LIGO Scientific Collaboration, the Virgo Collaboration, and the KAGRA Collaboration



                                                                                                  (Dated: June 30, 2021)




arXiv:2106.15163v1 [astro-ph.HE] 29 Jun 2021
                                                                                                      ABSTRACT
                                                         We report the observation of gravitational waves from two compact binary coalescences in LIGO’s
                                                       and Virgo’s third observing run with properties consistent with neutron star–black hole (NSBH)
                                                       binaries. The two events are named GW200105 162426 and GW200115 042309, abbreviated as
                                                       GW200105 and GW200115; the first was observed by LIGO Livingston and Virgo, and the second
                                                       by all three LIGO–Virgo detectors. The source of GW200105 has component masses 8.9+1.2    −1.5 M and
                                                       1.9+0.3
                                                          −0.2 M   , whereas the source of GW200115  has component    masses 5.7+1.8
                                                                                                                                −2.1 M    and 1.5 +0.7
                                                                                                                                                  −0.3 M (all
                                                       measurements quoted at the 90% credible level). The probability that the secondary’s mass is below
                                                       the maximal mass of a neutron star is 89%–96% and 87%–98%, respectively, for GW200105 and
                                                       GW200115, with the ranges arising from different astrophysical assumptions. The source luminosity
                                                       distances are 280+110                +150
                                                                         −110 Mpc and 300−100 Mpc, respectively. The magnitude of the primary spin of
                                                       GW200105 is less than 0.23 at the 90% credible level, and its orientation is unconstrained. For
                                                       GW200115, the primary spin has a negative spin projection onto the orbital angular momentum at
                                                       88% probability. We are unable to constrain the spin or tidal deformation of the secondary component
                                                       for either event. We infer an NSBH merger rate density of 45+75  −33 Gpc
                                                                                                                                −3
                                                                                                                                   yr−1 when assuming that
                                                       GW200105 and GW200115 are representative of the NSBH population, or 130+112    −69 Gpc
                                                                                                                                               −3
                                                                                                                                                   yr−1 under
                                                       the assumption of a broader distribution of component masses.

                                                                1. INTRODUCTION                                 NSBH-like parameters during the ∼11 months of the
                                                 In January 2020, the LIGO–Virgo detector net-                  third observing run (O3).
                                               work observed gravitational-wave (GW) signals from                  The component masses inferred from these binary in-
                                               two compact binary inspirals which are consistent                spirals provide information on the nature of their com-
                                               with neutron star–black hole (NSBH) binaries. These              ponents. The primaries have masses of m1 = 8.9+1.2
                                                                                                                                                                 −1.5 M
                                               represent the first confident observations to date of            and m1 = 5.7+1.8
                                                                                                                               −2.1 M , for GW200105     and  GW200115,
                                               NSBH binaries via any observational means. The two               respectively, with uncertainties quoted at the 90% cred-
                                               events, carrying the full designations GW200105 162426           ible level. These primary masses are well above the max-
                                               and GW200115 042309, and abbreviated henceforth as               imum mass of a neutron star (NS; Rhoades & Ruffini
                                               GW200105 and GW200115, were detected on January                  1974; Abbott et al. 2018a; Shibata et al. 2019; Cromar-
                                               05, 2020 at 16:24:26 UTC and January 15, 2020 at                 tie et al. 2019; Farr & Chatziioannou 2020; Nathanail
                                               04:23:10 UTC, respectively. The coincident detection             et al. 2021; Fonseca et al. 2021) and within the mass-
                                               of GW200115 by the three detectors LIGO Hanford,                 range of black holes (BHs) observed electromagnetically
                                               LIGO Livingston, and Virgo gives it high confidence              (Özel et al. 2010; Farr et al. 2011; Kreidberg et al.
                                               of being an astrophysical GW event. During the other             2012; Miller & Miller 2014) and via GWs (Abbott et al.
                                               event, GW200105, the LIGO Hanford detector was not               2016a, 2019a, 2021c). The masses of the secondaries are
                                               operational and, owing to the small signal-to-noise ra-          m2 = 1.9+0.3                   +0.7
                                                                                                                          −0.2 M and m2 = 1.5−0.3 M , respectively, for
                                               tio (S/N ) in Virgo, it was effectively a single-detector        GW200105 and GW200115, within the mass range of
                                               event in LIGO Livingston. While quantification of the            known NSs (Antoniadis et al. 2016; Alsing et al. 2018;
                                               confidence of single-detector events is subject to signifi-      Abbott et al. 2017a, 2020a).
                                               cant uncertainty, GW200105 stands clearly apart in the              Detections of NSBHs have so far remained elusive in
                                               LIGO Livingston data from any other candidate with               both electromagnetic (EM) and GW surveys. In the
                                                                                                                past four decades, surveys have identified 19 binary neu-

  During O3a, two events were notable as possible
NSBH candidates. First, GW190426 152155 (Abbott                          2. DETECTORS AND DATA

rate predictions: 0.1–800 Gpc−3 yr−1 (Belczynski et al.

                                                                                                                              3




Figure 1. Time–frequency representations of the data containing GW200105 (left column) and GW200115 (right column).
Times are shown relative to the signals’ merger times, January 05, 2020 at 16:24:26 UTC (left) and January 15, 2020 at 04:23:10
UTC (right). The amplitude scale of each time–frequency tile is normalized by the respective detector’s noise amplitude spectral
density. The LIGO Livingston data of GW200105 show a track of excess power with increasing frequency. In the other panels, no
similar tracks are visible, as the S/N in each of the detectors is lower and (for GW200115) the signal is longer. For GW200105,
the LIGO Livingston data are shown after glitch subtraction. For GW200115, light-scattering noise is visible in LIGO Livingston
below 25 Hz.
are for the LIGO detectors no larger than 8.6% in am-              environmental disturbances that could couple into the
plitude and 5.9◦ in phase for GW200105 and 8.0% in                 interferometers (Nguyen et al. 2021). In Virgo, we find
amplitude and 5.5◦ in phase for GW200115 (68% cred-                no evidence of excess power from terrestrial sources for
ible intervals). For Virgo, we use 5.0% in amplitude               both events. For GW200105, we identify light-scattering
and 4.1◦ in phase for both events, except for frequen-             noise in LIGO Livingston below 25 Hz, 3 s before merger.
cies 46–51 Hz, where additional calibration systematic             As in past detections (Abbott et al. 2021c), we sub-
error arises from online loops set up to damp the main             tract this noise with the BayesWave algorithm (Cornish
power lines at 50 Hz and mechanical resonances of the              et al. 2021) and use the cleaned data for the source pa-
suspensions close to 48 Hz. This effect was introduced             rameter estimation in §4. The top left panel of Fig. 1
during detector improvements carried out between O3a               shows the cleaned data. A low-energy feature around
and O3b and is not accounted for in the signal recon-              20 Hz, not overlapping with the time–frequency track
struction process. However, Virgo data in the frequency            of GW200105, remains after the glitch subtraction. For
window 46–51 Hz are excluded from the parameter esti-              GW200115, we also identify light scattering in the LIGO
mation analyses in §4.                                             Livingston data below 25 Hz. Due to the increased dif-

           3.1. GW200115 – Multi-detector event                 RAVEN pipeline (Urban 2016), which looks for coinci-
  GW200115 was initially identified by all four low-            dent gamma ray bursts (GRBs), did not report an asso-
latency matched-filtering pipelines as a possible com-          ciated GRB trigger from Fermi-GBM or the Neil Gehrels
pact binary coalescence (CBC) candidate in LIGO Han-            Swift Observatory within −1 s and +5 s of the GW trig-
ford and LIGO Livingston: GstLAL (Cannon et al.                 ger. A total of 31 GCN Circulars (GCN archive for
2012; Privitera et al. 2014; Messick et al. 2017; Sachdev       S200115j 2020) reporting follow-up observations were
et al. 2019; Hanna et al. 2020), MBTAOnline (Aubin              published for this event. To date, no EM counterpart
et al. 2021; Adams et al. 2016), PyCBC Live (Dal Can-           has been reported associated with GW200115.
ton et al. 2020; Nitz et al. 2018, 2019, 2017; Usman               After the low-latency identification of GW200115, the
et al. 2016), and SPIIR (Luan et al. 2012; Hooper et al.        extended periods of strain data around the event are
2012; Chu et al. 2020; Guo et al. 2018). As detailed            further analyzed by the detection pipelines in their of-
in Abbott et al. (2021c), matched-filtering searches use        fline configurations using improved calibration and re-
banks (Owen & Sathyaprakash 1999; Harry et al. 2009;            fined data quality information that is not available in low
Privitera et al. 2014; Roy et al. 2017, 2019) of modeled        latency (Abbott et al. 2018b, 2021c; Davis et al. 2021).
gravitational waveforms, with the mass range relevant           In this analysis, we also subtract nonstationary noise
to GW200105 and GW200115 covered by the SEOB-                   due to the nonlinear coupling of the 60 Hz power mains
                                                                                                                          5

at the LIGO detectors using coupling functions derived
from machine-learning techniques (Vajente et al. 2020).
  PyCBC uses a template bank constructed with a
hybrid geometric-random algorithm (Roy et al. 2019,
2017), while GstLAL and MBTA use a template bank
generated by a stochastic placement method (Mukher-
jee et al. 2021; Babak 2008; Privitera et al. 2014). Gst-
LAL identifies GW200115 with a network S/N of 11.6
and FAR of < 1/(1×105 yr) using the data from Novem-
ber 1, 2019 15:00 UTC to January 22, 2020 18:11 UTC.
The MBTA and PyCBC offline analyses also identified
the trigger in data from January 13, 2020 10:27 UTC
to January 22, 2020 18:11 UTC, yielding consistent net-

for GW190425 (Abbott et al. 2020a).                           use a low-frequency cutoff of flow = 20 Hz, except for

the marginal candidate GW190426 152155 separately                We base our main analyses of GW200105 and
for LIGO Livingston and LIGO Hanford. In general,             GW200115 on BBH waveform models that include the
triggers such as GW200115 and GW190426 152155 in              effects of spin-induced orbital precession and higher-
Fig. 3 would not be separable from the noise by a single      order multipole GW moments, but do not include tidal
detector alone, and it is the coincidence between multi-      effects on the secondary. Specifically, we use two sig-
ple detectors that raises their significance. On the other    nal models: IMRPhenomXPHM (Phenom PHM; Prat-
hand, the coincidence was not available for GW200105,         ten et al. 2020) from the phenomenological family and
yet it clearly stands out from the background in Fig. 3       SEOBNRv4PHM (EOBNR PHM; Ossokine et al. 2020)
as strong GW signals typically do.                            from the effective one-body numerical relativity family.
   The uniqueness of GW200105 within the data shown           The acronym PHM stands for Precessing Higher-order
leads to a upper bound on the FAR assignment compa-           multipole Moments. Henceforth, we will use the short-
rable to the inverse observing time. A stronger bound,        ened names for the waveform models.
like the FAR quoted above, must rely on assumptions              In order to quantify the impact of neglecting tidal ef-
made on the properties of the noise triggers if one had       fects, we also analyze GW200105 and GW200115 us-
collected the observational strain data for a longer pe-      ing two NSBH waveform models that include tidal ef-
riod, a process called extrapolation. As a consequence of     fects and assume that spins are aligned with the or-
the assumptions made, the extrapolated FAR estimates          bital angular momentum: IMRPhenomNSBH (Phe-
have large uncertainties. Since single-detector FAR es-       nom NSBH; Thompson et al. 2020) and SEOB-
timates rely on the uniqueness within the dataset, the        NRv4 ROM NRTidalv2 NSBH (EOBNR NSBH; Matas
values may change and errors may reduce as more data          et al. 2020). We restrict the NSBH analyses to the region
are accumulated. At the time of the analysis, nei-            of applicability of the NSBH models, i.e. χ1 < 0.5, χ2 <
ther MBTA nor PyCBC had the capability to as-                 0.05 for Phenom NSBH and χ1 < 0.9, χ2 < 0.05 for
sign a significance to single-detector triggers, although     EOBNR NSBH. We also perform aligned-spin BBH
GW200105 also stands out as a unique trigger in their         waveform analyses and find good agreement with the
analyses. Based on these considerations, we consider          analyses using NSBH waveform models (see §4.6 below),
this trigger to be astrophysical and include it in the        validating the use of BBH waveform models. Specif-
analysis in the remainder of this paper.                      ically, we use the aligned-spin BBH models IMRPhe-
                                                                                                                               7

Figure 6.         Two-dimensional posterior probability for the spin-tilt angle and spin magnitude for the primary objects
(left hemispheres) and secondary objects (right hemispheres) for both events. Spin-tilt angles of 0° (180°) correspond to
spins aligned (antialigned) with the orbital anglular momentum. The color indicates the posterior probability per pixel of
the high-spin prior analysis. For comparison with the low-spin analysis, the solid (dashed) lines indicate the 90% credible
regions of the high-spin (low-spin) prior analyses. The tiles are constructed linearly in spin magnitude and the cosine of the
tilt angles such that each tile contains an identical prior probability. The probabilities are marginalized over the azimuthal angles.

10

                                                                   4.5. Tests of general relativity and higher-order GW
                                                                                      multipole moments
                                                                     Results from parameterized tests of general relativ-
                                                                  ity (GR; Blanchet & Sathyaprakash 1995; Yunes & Pre-
                                                                  torius 2009; Mishra et al. 2010; Li et al. 2012a,b; Agathos
                                                                  et al. 2014; Meidam et al. 2018; Abbott et al. 2019b),
                                                                  show that GW200105 and GW200115 have too low an
                                                                  S/N to allow for tighter constraints than those already
                                                                  presented in Abbott et al. (2021d). Within their mea-
                                                                  surement uncertainties, our results do not show statis-
                                                                  tically significant evidence for deviations from the pre-
                                                                  diction of GR.
                                                                     To quantify the evidence for higher-order GW multi-
                                                                  pole moments, we calculate the orthogonal optimal S/N
                                                                  ρ⊥lm for the subdominant multipole moments (Abbott
                                                                  et al. 2020c,d; Mills & Fairhurst 2021). We find the
                                                                  (`, |m|) = (3, 3) to be the loudest subdominant multi-
                                                                  pole moment, as expected for binaries with asymmet-
                                                                  ric masses. Using the Phenom HM waveform model,
                                                                                       +0.92      +0.94
                                                                  we infer ρ⊥33 = 1.70−1.09 (1.70−1.11 ) for GW200105 and
                                                                    ⊥         +0.93      +0.90
Figure 7.        Properties of the primary component of           ρ33 = 0.91−0.66 (0.86−0.65 ) for GW200115 with the low
GW200115. The corner plot shows the one-dimensional (di-          (high) spin prior. In Gaussian noise, the median of ρ⊥ 33 is
agonal) and two-dimensional (off-diagonal) marginal poste-        approximately chi-distributed with two degrees of free-
rior distributions for the primary’s mass and perpendicular       dom, and values greater than 2.1 indicate significant
and parallel spin components. The shading indicates the
                                                                  higher-order multipole content. The measured ρ⊥      33 are
posterior probability of the high-spin prior analysis. The
solid (dashed) lines indicate the 50% and 90% credible re-        therefore consistent with Gaussian noise, as expected for
gions of the high-spin (low-spin) prior analyses. The vertical    the majority of NSBHs at these S/Ns, except for those
lines indicate the 90% credible intervals for the analyses with   viewed close to edge-on.
high-spin (solid lines) and low-spin (dashed lines) prior.

to see notable systematic effects. We observe differences              ments changes the posterior contours more substantially
at the extreme ends of the m2 –χeff contours (i.e. at the              than inclusion of tides. We conclude that the the inclu-
smallest and largest values of m2 ). The construction                  sion of precession and higher-order multipole moments
of the NSBH waveform models used here did not rely                     afforded by the BBH waveform models is more impor-
on numerical relativity results at mass ratios q . 1/8,                tant than the impact of tides in the NSBH models.
nor did they include simulations with χ1z < 0 or NS
masses m2 > 1.4M (Matas et al. 2020; Thompson
et al. 2020). Therefore, some differences should be ex-                5. NATURE OF THE SECONDARY COMPONENTS
pected, especially for large m2 in GW200105. Further-                    In this section, we describe the investigations to es-
more, for GW200105, the tails of the m2 –χeff distribu-                tablish the nature of the secondary objects. In §5.1, we
tion for Phenom NSBH and EOB NSBH at high m2 are                       look for imprints of tidal deformations of the secondaries
also impacted by the inability of the data to constrain                and conclude that the masses, spins, distances and S/Ns
the tidal deformability. Hence, the posterior samples                  of the detections make definitive identifications of NSs
include combinations of high m2 with large Λ2 , despite                unlikely, both in GW and EM measurements. However,
such combinations being unphysical. This effect is not                 in §5.2, we show that the posterior distributions of the
apparent for GW200115 because of its smaller secondary                 secondary masses agree with those of known NSs.

     5.1. Tidal deformability and tidal disruption           Table 3. Probability that the secondary mass is below the
                                                             maximum NS mass Mmax for each event, given different spin
   The tidal deformability of NSs is imprinted in the GW     assumptions and different choices for the maximum NS mass.
signal, and is investigated using the parameter estima-      The values shown use a flat prior in m2 ; alternative, astro-
tion techniques of §4. In contrast, BHs have zero tidal      physically motivated mass priors, can cause the estimates to
deformability (Binnington & Poisson 2009; Damour &           vary by up to 11% across our chosen models.
Nagar 2009; Chia 2020; Charalambous et al. 2021; Le
Tiec & Casals 2021). We infer the tidal deformabil-
                                                                                                 p(m2 < Mmax )
ity Λ2 of the NSs in GW200105 and GW200115 using
                                                               spin prior    choice of Mmax   GW200105 GW200115
the NSBH waveform models that include tides. We find
that the tidal deformabilities are uninformative relative     |χ2 | < 0.05     Mmax,TOV          96%           98%
to a uniform prior in Λ2 ∈ [0, 5000]. This measurement        |χ2 | < 0.99     Mmax (χ2 )        94%           95%
cannot establish the presence of NSs, which is expected       |χ2 | < 0.99     Mmax,GNS          93%           96%
given the mass ratios and the S/N of the detections (Fou-
cart et al. 2013; Kumar et al. 2017; Fasano et al. 2020;
Huang et al. 2020).                                            Estimating the impact of nonlinear p–g tidal coupling
   Toward the end of the inspiral, the BH may tidally        (Abbott et al. 2019c), we find that it would produce
disrupt the NS and form an accretion disk (Pannar-           a relative frequency-domain phase shift for GW200105
ale 2013; Foucart et al. 2018). This is hypothesized to      (GW200115) of approximately 134 (38) times smaller
drive a relativistic jet (Pannarale et al. 2011; Pascha-     than the equivalent phase shift for GW170817. This
lidis et al. 2015). Given the mass ratios for both events    strongly reduced effect is caused by the larger chirp
and the aligned spins χ1,z of their primaries (near zero     masses, more asymmetric mass ratios, and the presence
for GW200105, probably negative for GW200115), we            of only a single NS. Since p–g effects were not detected
do not expect tidal disruption to occur, which would re-     for GW170817 (Abbott et al. 2019c), they will be unob-
quire more equal masses or more positive χ1,z (Rantsiou      servable within the new NSBH systems.
et al. 2008; Shibata & Taniguchi 2008; Etienne et al.
2009; Foucart et al. 2011; Kyutoku et al. 2011; Pannar-        5.2. Consistency of component masses with the NS
ale 2013; Foucart et al. 2018).                                                    maximum mass
   To quantitatively confirm this expectation, we use          Even without definite identification of matter signa-
the spectral representation of equations of state from       tures in the signals, we can compare the observed m2
Abbott et al. (2018a), which uses an SLY low-density         for GW200105 and GW200115 with the maximum NS
crust model (Douchin & Haensel 2001) and parame-             mass, Mmax . The existence of massive pulsars (Anto-
terizes the adiabatic index into a polynomial in the         niadis et al. 2013; Cromartie et al. 2019; Fonseca et al.
logarithm of the pressure (Lindblom 2010; Lindblom           2021) places a lower bound of Mmax & 2 M on the
& Indik 2012, 2014). Following Stachie et al. (2021),        maximum NS mass. Studies of GW170817’s remnant

mass Mmax (χ2 ), and the breakup spin χmax with the
universal relations from Breu & Rezzolla (2016). In this
scenario, we require m2 ≤ Mmax (χ2 ) and χ2 ≤ χmax
for consistency with an NS. Finally, in the third row,
we consider a parametric fit to the entire distribution
of observed Galactic NSs, including rapidly rotating
pulsars (Farr & Chatziioannou 2020), which predicts
                  +0.71
Mmax,GNS = 2.25−0.31    M , and is shown in Fig. 4. This
scenario accounts for the possibility that the maximum
mass in the NS population is limited by the astrophysi-
cal processes that form compact binaries. Assuming low
spin (first row), we find probabilities of 96% and 98%

fect the component mass posteriors for detections with        The first confident observations of NSBH binaries en-
moderate S/N. To illustrate the impact of population        able us to study this novel type of astrophysical system
assumptions, we consider three alternative priors: one      in entirely new ways. We pursue three different avenues
based on Salpeter mass distributions, p(m) ∼ m−2.3          in this section. First, we infer the merger rate of NSBH
(Salpeter 1955), independently for each component; one      binaries in the local universe. We then place the inferred
based on an extrapolation of the BBH mass model Bro-        source properties and merger rate in the context of mod-
ken Power Law from Abbott et al. (2021b) down to            els of NSBH formation channels and previous EM and
0.5 M for both components; and another based on a           GW observations of BHs and NSs. Finally, we investi-
similar extrapolation of the Power Law + Peak BBH           gate to what extent the events reported here can serve
mass model from the same study. We marginalize over         to measure the Hubble constant and whether lensing of
the uncertainties in the latter two models, which are fit   GWs may have played a role in the observations.
to the BBH population from Abbott et al. (2021c), in-
cluding the outlier event GW190814 with a secondary                         6.1. Merger rate density

naries. Specifically, we consider triggers across O1, O2        compact object binaries distinguish between NSs and
and the first nine months of O3 with associated com-            BHs with a simple mass cut, typically between 2 and
ponent masses m1 ∈ [2.5, 40] M and m2 ∈ [1, 3] M ,              3 M . This is consistent with the secondary masses of

1974; Kalogera & Baym 1996). The population is de-                              6.2.1. Formation channels

uniform in log component masses in the given ranges,

with aligned spins with spin magnitudes distributed uni-

formly in [0, 0.95]. We use as input GstLAL search

triggers above an S/N threshold such that the number

nals by a factor ∼100. Following Farr et al. (2015); Ka-

padia et al. (2020), we find the resulting joint likelihood
